#Text=Thomas Pope ( actor )
#Text=Thomas Pope ( died 1603 ) was an Elizabethan actor , a member of the Lord Chamberlain 's Men and a colleague of William Shakespeare . [ 1 ]
#Text=Pope was a " comedian and acrobat . " [ 2 ]

column1: #Text=Beginnings
#Text=Nothing is known of Pope 's early life .
#Text=He was one of the English players who toured Denmark and Saxony in 1586 – 87 , along with George Bryan , another future Chamberlain 's man .

#Text=He was in the production of The Seven Deadly Sins c. 1591 , which was performed by a combination of personnel from Lord Strange 's Men and the Admiral 's Men , and which starred Edward Alleyn and included Bryan , Richard Burbage , Augustine Phillips , Richard Cowley , and John Sinklo , all soon-to-be Lord Chamberlain 's Men .
#Text=Pope toured with Lord Strange 's Men under Edward Alleyn in 1593 , with most of the same personnel .
#Text=Chamberlain 's
#Text=Pope was most likely an original member of the Lord Chamberlain 's Men at their re-constitution in 1594 , along with Shakespeare , Burbage , and the others .

#Text=He was a figure of some significance in the early phase of the company 's history , in that he and Heminges were the payees for their Court performances — a responsibility that would have been given only to trusted members .

#Text=Though no information has survived on his specific roles , it is thought that his physique and style most suited the comic character of stout , braggartly cowards , such as Falstaff and Sir Toby Belch , although he is also conjectured to have performed in dramatic roles , such as Mercutio and Shylock .
#Text=He was also cast in the two Ben Jonson plays acted by the company in the late 1590s , Every Man in His Humour ( 1598 ) and Every Man Out of His Humour ( 1599 ) .
#Text=In 1599 he also became one of the original sharers in the new Globe Theatre .
#Text=He was no longer part of the company when they became the King 's Men in 1603 ; he might have been retired by then , and in fact died in that year .
#Text=Like some other actors and members of his troupe ( Shakespeare ; Phillips ) , Pope lived in Southwark , near the theatres ; he is thought to have remained unmarried .
#Text=Post mortem
#Text=Pope 's last will and testament was dated 22 July 1603 ( and probated on 13 February 1604 ) .
#Text=He left legacies to two other actors , one of whom was Robert Gough , an actor with the Lord Chamberlain 's Men who continued with the King 's Men after 1603 .
#Text=The other was a John Edmans , or Edmonds .
#Text=Pope left Gough and Edmans " all my wearing apparel , and all my arms , to be equally divided between them . " [ 3 ]
#Text=Pope also left his share in the Globe , and a share in the Curtain Theatre , to a Mary Clark ;
#Text=in 1612 the Globe share was owned by a John and Mary Edmans — she , presumably , being the former Mary Clark .

#Text=The fact that Pope owned a share in the Curtain Theatre , where the Lord Chamberlain 's Men had acted in the 1597 – 99 era , is significant for an understanding of an important facet of the development of English Renaissance theatre . [ For the importance of the Curtain shares , see : John Underwood . ]
